elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">The reaction between a double-betaine-containing ligand and DyH[PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]·nH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O led to a new polyoxometalate-based lanthanide-organic hybrid compound with the molecular formula [Dy(HL)(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]·8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1) (L<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(pyridinil-4-carboxylato)-l,4-dimethylbenzene). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was characterized by elemental analyses, TG, IR, XPS and the single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses a cationic 1D polymeric chain [Dy(HL)(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">4n+</ce:sup> with cyclic-, chain- and semi-cyclic-like fragments, corresponding to three different configurations of the double-betaine-containing ligand. These 1D chains are connected together by the H-bonds and π–π interactions to form a 3D supramolecular framework, encapsulating the vanadium-substituted Keggin-type polyoxoanions [PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>and the solvent molecules. This composite compound displays electrocatalytic activities towards the reduction of nitrite and the luminescent property.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The reaction between a double-betaine-containing ligand and DyH[PMo11VO40]⋅nH2O led to a new polyoxometalate-based lanthanide-organic hybrid compound with the molecular formula [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3][PMo11VO40]⋅8H2O (1) (L=1,4-bis(pyridinil-4-carboxylato)-l,4-dimethylbenzene). Compound 1 was characterized by elemental analyses, TG, IR, XPS and the single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 possesses a cationic 1D polymeric chain [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3]n 4n+ with cyclic-, chain- and semi-cyclic-like fragments, corresponding to three different configurations of the double-betaine-containing ligand. These 1D chains are connected together by the H-bonds and π-π interactions to form a 3D supramolecular framework, encapsulating the vanadium-substituted Keggin-type polyoxoanions [PMo11VO40]4-and the solvent molecules. This composite compound displays electrocatalytic activities towards the reduction of nitrite and the luminescent property.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The reaction between a double-betaine-containing ligand and LnHPMo11VO40⋅nH2O leads to a new polyoxometalate-based lanthanide-organic hybrid chain.     

Highlights

► In this study we report a new polyoxometalate(POM)-based lanthanide-organic hybrid compound. ► The exchange of POMs can tune the structure of the lanthanide-organic coordination fragments. ► Interestingly, the betaine-containing ligands in 1 exhibit three different configurations. ► Compound 1 displays both luminescent and electrocatalytic activities.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Organic–inorganic hybrid materials have been regarded as a new generation of solid-state materials due to not only their chemical and structural diversities but also to their potential applications in many research fields such as catalysis, gas storage, separation and molecular recognition . In the last decade, such materials have been significantly developed by the modification of organic ligands and/or inorganic metal oxide fragments . During the synthesis, various inorganic anions have been introduced as counter ions and inducers to assemble new hybrid materials . However, the modification of inorganic anions is usually impeded by the limited species in contrast to the abundant organic ligands. In this aspect, polyoxometalates (POMs), as one type of unique nano-sized metal-oxo clusters, can be excellent anionic precursors due to their controllable shape, size and high negative charges, as well as their potential advantages in the design of new materials with abundant chemical combinations and multiple functionalities . In the POM-based hybrid compounds, most efforts have been focused on the construction of new hybrids with transition metal (TM) ions, various neutral organic N-donor ligands, and the polyoxoanions . By contrast, the analogs based on lanthanide-organic hybrid moieties and POM building units have rarely been reported . Considering that the introduction of lanthanide into the POM-based composite materials may induce new functionalities such as luminescent, magnetic, and/or catalytic properties , thus, the design and synthesis of new POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid materials become a currently new research topic. However, many N-donor linking ligands are not easy to coordinate with lanthanide ions, especially in the acidic media. Furthermore, the oxophilic lanthanide ions usually possess high reactivity with oxygen-enriched POMs, which always lead to precipitate instead of crystallization . Moreover, if the anionic carboxyl-containing ligands were employed, the reaction competition between carboxylate group and the polyoxoanions with the lanthanide cations cannot be avoided, which always lead to uncontrollable results . Therefore, the design and synthesis of new POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid compounds is still a great challenge.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Organic-inorganic hybrid materials have been regarded as a new generation of solid-state materials due to not only their chemical and structural diversities but also to their potential applications in many research fields such as catalysis, gas storage, separation and molecular recognition . In the last decade, such materials have been significantly developed by the modification of organic ligands and/or inorganic metal oxide fragments . During the synthesis, various inorganic anions have been introduced as counter ions and inducers to assemble new hybrid materials . However, the modification of inorganic anions is usually impeded by the limited species in contrast to the abundant organic ligands. In this aspect, polyoxometalates (POMs), as one type of unique nano-sized metal-oxo clusters, can be excellent anionic precursors due to their controllable shape, size and high negative charges, as well as their potential advantages in the design of new materials with abundant chemical combinations and multiple functionalities . In the POM-based hybrid compounds, most efforts have been focused on the construction of new hybrids with transition metal (TM) ions, various neutral organic N-donor ligands, and the polyoxoanions . By contrast, the analogs based on lanthanide-organic hybrid moieties and POM building units have rarely been reported . Considering that the introduction of lanthanide into the POM-based composite materials may induce new functionalities such as luminescent, magnetic, and/or catalytic properties , thus, the design and synthesis of new POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid materials become a currently new research topic. However, many N-donor linking ligands are not easy to coordinate with lanthanide ions, especially in the acidic media. Furthermore, the oxophilic lanthanide ions usually possess high reactivity with oxygen-enriched POMs, which always lead to precipitate instead of crystallization . Moreover, if the anionic carboxyl-containing ligands were employed, the reaction competition between carboxylate group and the polyoxoanions with the lanthanide cations cannot be avoided, which always lead to uncontrollable results . Therefore, the design and synthesis of new POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid compounds is still a great challenge.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">To avoid aforementioned problems, the double betaine-containing ligands enter into our eyes. Such betaine-type ligands usually exhibit the zwitterionic properties and overall charge neutrality, containing both anionic carboxylate groups and cationic amino groups . In comparison to the anionic double-carboxyl-containing ligands, the double-betaine-type ligands may not only retain the diverse coordination modes of carboxylate groups but also offer a new type of neutral O-donor linkers . Therefore, we chose a flexible double-betaine-containing ligand, that is, the 1,4-bis(pyridinil-4-carboxylato)-l,4-dimethylbenzene (L)  (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>), and have successfully synthesized a new 2-D lanthanide-organic hybrid network templated by the Keggin-type polyoxoanion [PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>
. As a continuing work of this reaction system, we modified the POMs [PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> into the vanadium-substituted POMs [PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> in order to explore the influence of different POMs on the lanthanide-organic hybrid scaffoldings. Interestingly, the modification of POMs leads to the isolation of a new POM-based 1-D lanthanide-organic hybrid chain with the molecular formula [Dy(HL)(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] [PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]·8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To avoid aforementioned problems, the double betaine-containing ligands enter into our eyes. Such betaine-type ligands usually exhibit the zwitterionic properties and overall charge neutrality, containing both anionic carboxylate groups and cationic amino groups . In comparison to the anionic double-carboxyl-containing ligands, the double-betaine-type ligands may not only retain the diverse coordination modes of carboxylate groups but also offer a new type of neutral O-donor linkers . Therefore, we chose a flexible double-betaine-containing ligand, that is, the 1,4-bis(pyridinil-4-carboxylato)-l,4-dimethylbenzene (L)  (see  ), and have successfully synthesized a new 2-D lanthanide-organic hybrid network templated by the Keggin-type polyoxoanion [PMo12O40]3- . As a continuing work of this reaction system, we modified the POMs [PMo12O40]3- into the vanadium-substituted POMs [PMo11VO40]4- in order to explore the influence of different POMs on the lanthanide-organic hybrid scaffoldings. Interestingly, the modification of POMs leads to the isolation of a new POM-based 1-D lanthanide-organic hybrid chain with the molecular formula [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3] [PMo11VO40]⋅8H2O (1) .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  shows that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1, and the basic structural unit consists of the cationic lanthanide-organic hybrid chain [Dy(HL)(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup>, the Keggin-type polyoxoanion [PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>, and eight lattice water molecules (Fig. S1 and Fig. S2). In the cationic dysprosium-organic chain of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each Dy<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion adopts an octa-coordinated environment with five oxygen atoms derived from the carboxylate groups of three different L ligands and three coordinated water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The bond distances of Dy<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O are in the range of 2.230(17)–2.592(14) Å and the O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Dy<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond angles vary from 52.1(5)° to 159.6(7)°. It is interesting that the L ligands can be regarded as three different types labeled with L<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf>, L<ce:inf loc="post">b</ce:inf> and L<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf> as shown in b. Although each carboxylate group on the L<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> and L<ce:inf loc="post">b</ce:inf> ligands displays a monodentate coordination mode with one Dy center, L<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> and L<ce:inf loc="post">b</ce:inf> ligands exhibit two different configurations, that is, the L<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> ligand adopts cis-configuration and the L<ce:inf loc="post">b</ce:inf> ligand possesses trans-configuration (a and b). For L<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf> ligand, one carboxylate group exhibits a bidentate coordination mode with one Dy center and the other carboxylate group is protonated (a and b). Based on above coordination mode, each Dy1 atom connects Dy2 atom via two L<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> ligands to form a cyclic-like unit (a and c). Furthermore, the Dy1 atom on each circle unit links the Dy2 atom on the other cyclic unit via the linear L<ce:inf loc="post">b</ce:inf> ligand to form an infinite 1D chain. Moreover, each Dy center also connects one semi-cyclic-like L<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf> ligand (a and c). Such a structural feature just looks like a “train” with many semi-open cavities that can carry “guest” polyoxoanions (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  shows that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1, and the basic structural unit consists of the cationic lanthanide-organic hybrid chain [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3]4+, the Keggin-type polyoxoanion [PMo11VO40]4-, and eight lattice water molecules (Fig. S1 and Fig. S2). In the cationic dysprosium-organic chain of 1, each Dy3+ ion adopts an octa-coordinated environment with five oxygen atoms derived from the carboxylate groups of three different L ligands and three coordinated water molecules ( ). The bond distances of DyO are in the range of 2.230(17)-2.592(14) Å and the ODyO bond angles vary from 52.1(5)° to 159.6(7)°. It is interesting that the L ligands can be regarded as three different types labeled with La, Lb and Lc as shown in b. Although each carboxylate group on the La and Lb ligands displays a monodentate coordination mode with one Dy center, La and Lb ligands exhibit two different configurations, that is, the La ligand adopts cis-configuration and the Lb ligand possesses trans-configuration (a and b). For Lc ligand, one carboxylate group exhibits a bidentate coordination mode with one Dy center and the other carboxylate group is protonated (a and b). Based on above coordination mode, each Dy1 atom connects Dy2 atom via two La ligands to form a cyclic-like unit (a and c). Furthermore, the Dy1 atom on each circle unit links the Dy2 atom on the other cyclic unit via the linear Lb ligand to form an infinite 1D chain. Moreover, each Dy center also connects one semi-cyclic-like Lc ligand (a and c). Such a structural feature just looks like a "train" with many semi-open cavities that can carry "guest" polyoxoanions (c).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">In the packing arrangement, the adjacent 1D chains are linked together to form a 2D supramolecular network via the hydrogen bonds between the coordination water molecules (O1w) and the carboxylate groups (O50) from the adjacent 1D chains along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (a, b<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor> and Fig. S3). The typical H-bond length of O1w…O50 is 2.486<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (a and Fig. S3). Moreover, two adjacent supramolecular networks possess π–π interactions to form the 3D supramolecular framework (c and d). The vanadium-substituted Keggin-type polyoxoanions [PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> and solvent water molecules are encapsulated in the cavities between two adjacent 2D supramolecular networks. From our previous reported compounds  and this work (compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), it is found that the POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid scaffoldings can be adjusted by changing various lanthanide cations and modifying the polyoxoanions. To our knowledge, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> represents the first vanadium-substituted Keggin-type POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid compound.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the packing arrangement, the adjacent 1D chains are linked together to form a 2D supramolecular network via the hydrogen bonds between the coordination water molecules (O1w) and the carboxylate groups (O50) from the adjacent 1D chains along a axis (a, b and Fig. S3). The typical H-bond length of O1w…O50 is 2.486Å (a and Fig. S3). Moreover, two adjacent supramolecular networks possess π-π interactions to form the 3D supramolecular framework (c and d). The vanadium-substituted Keggin-type polyoxoanions [PMo11VO40]4- and solvent water molecules are encapsulated in the cavities between two adjacent 2D supramolecular networks. From our previous reported compounds  and this work (compound 1), it is found that the POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid scaffoldings can be adjusted by changing various lanthanide cations and modifying the polyoxoanions. To our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first vanadium-substituted Keggin-type POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid compound.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The polyoxoanion [PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> shows interesting reversible multi-electron redox processes . Thus, it is interesting to explore its electrochemical behaviors and changes when such multi-electron carrier is encapsulated into the cationic metal–organic open frameworks. Herein, the electrochemical behaviors of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>were investigated with the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-modified carbon paste electrodes (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE) because of its very low solubility in water and common organic solvents. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE at different scan rates were measured in the potential range from +<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>800 to −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV in 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.1 Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). As shown in a, four pairs of reversible redox peaks of 1-CPE appear in the range of +<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>800 to −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV, and the mean peak potentials (<ce:bold>
<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>(<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">cp</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>
<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">ap</ce:inf>)/2) are 502, 363,221 and −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV with the scan rate of 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV/s (Fig. S5). The reversible peak I–I’ is attributable to a one-electron redox process of V center and the reversible peaks II–II’, III–III’ and IV-IV’ correspond to a two-, four-, and six-electron redox process of Mo centers, respectively . The peak currents are proportional to the scan rate up to 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV/s, indicating that the redox process of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE is surface-controlled (a inset).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The polyoxoanion [PMo11VO40]4- shows interesting reversible multi-electron redox processes . Thus, it is interesting to explore its electrochemical behaviors and changes when such multi-electron carrier is encapsulated into the cationic metal-organic open frameworks. Herein, the electrochemical behaviors of compound 1were investigated with the 1-modified carbon paste electrodes (1-CPE) because of its very low solubility in water and common organic solvents. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements of 1-CPE at different scan rates were measured in the potential range from +800 to -150mV in 0.5M H2SO4 +0.1 Na2SO4 (a). As shown in a, four pairs of reversible redox peaks of 1-CPE appear in the range of +800 to -150mV, and the mean peak potentials ( E  1/2 =(E cp +  E  ap)/2) are 502, 363,221 and -25mV with the scan rate of 100mV/s (Fig. S5). The reversible peak I-I' is attributable to a one-electron redox process of V center and the reversible peaks II-II', III-III' and IV-IV' correspond to a two-, four-, and six-electron redox process of Mo centers, respectively . The peak currents are proportional to the scan rate up to 200mV/s, indicating that the redox process of 1-CPE is surface-controlled (a inset).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In the electrochemical studies of POM-based hybrid materials, one of the most interesting works is to discover their potential electrocatalytic properties, since many of them can be potentially good electrocatalysts to reduce the polluting substances in water such as iodate, nitrite and hydrogen peroxide . Especially when the POMs are combined into the metal–organic frameworks, they can not only avoid the partial loss in organic and/or aqueous media but also retain the electrocatalytic activity, representing one type of ideal electrocatalysts. The electrocatalytic properties of 1-CPEs were studied toward the reduction of nitrite in an aqueous solution. At <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE in a 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.1 Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> aqueous solution, the CV for the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrite is shown in b. With the addition of nitrite solution, all reduction peak currents increased while the corresponding oxidation peak currents markedly decreased, revealing that nitrite was reduced by all reduced polyoxoanion species. It is worth emphasizing that the fourth reduced species shows the best electrocatalytic activity, suggesting that the increase of reduction extent of the Keggin anion species may enhance their catalytic activities. It's also noteworthy that no obvious response was observed in the range +<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>800 to −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV on a bare CPE and the reduction of nitrite at a bare electrode generally requires a large overpotential (b). Moreover, the peak currents of 1-CPE keep almost unchanged over 100 cycles at a scan rate of 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV/s when the potential range is maintained between +<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>800 and −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mV, indicating that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-CPE possesses a relatively high stability .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the electrochemical studies of POM-based hybrid materials, one of the most interesting works is to discover their potential electrocatalytic properties, since many of them can be potentially good electrocatalysts to reduce the polluting substances in water such as iodate, nitrite and hydrogen peroxide . Especially when the POMs are combined into the metal-organic frameworks, they can not only avoid the partial loss in organic and/or aqueous media but also retain the electrocatalytic activity, representing one type of ideal electrocatalysts. The electrocatalytic properties of 1-CPEs were studied toward the reduction of nitrite in an aqueous solution. At 1-CPE in a 0.5M H2SO4 +0.1 Na2SO4 aqueous solution, the CV for the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrite is shown in b. With the addition of nitrite solution, all reduction peak currents increased while the corresponding oxidation peak currents markedly decreased, revealing that nitrite was reduced by all reduced polyoxoanion species. It is worth emphasizing that the fourth reduced species shows the best electrocatalytic activity, suggesting that the increase of reduction extent of the Keggin anion species may enhance their catalytic activities. It's also noteworthy that no obvious response was observed in the range +800 to -150mV on a bare CPE and the reduction of nitrite at a bare electrode generally requires a large overpotential (b). Moreover, the peak currents of 1-CPE keep almost unchanged over 100 cycles at a scan rate of 100mV/s when the potential range is maintained between +800 and -150mV, indicating that 1-CPE possesses a relatively high stability .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The luminescent property of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has also been explored. Intense emission peak of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is located at 423<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 368<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>) and can be ascribed to organic ligand-based emission according to the luminescence spectrum of the free L ligand (). This emission band can be assigned to a π–π* or π–n ligand-centered electronic transition within the aromatic systems of the L ligand . But the characteristic emission band of Dy<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion cannot be observed. It is presumed that the aqua ligands on these lanthanide ions may lead to the fluorescence quenching . The above observations suggest that this POM-based composite material of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be suitable candidates for potential fluorescent materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The luminescent property of compound 1 has also been explored. Intense emission peak of compound 1 is located at 423nm upon excitation at 368nm ( ) and can be ascribed to organic ligand-based emission according to the luminescence spectrum of the free L ligand (). This emission band can be assigned to a π-π* or π-n ligand-centered electronic transition within the aromatic systems of the L ligand . But the characteristic emission band of Dy3+ ion cannot be observed. It is presumed that the aqua ligands on these lanthanide ions may lead to the fluorescence quenching . The above observations suggest that this POM-based composite material of 1 may be suitable candidates for potential fluorescent materials.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The XPS spectra of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> confirm that the polyoxoanion of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains both V(V) and Mo(VI) centers. The binding energy peak at 517.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV corresponds to 2p<ce:sup loc="post">3/2</ce:sup> of the V(V) center (Fig. S6a) , while the peaks at 235.7 and 232.55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV are assigned to 3d<ce:sup loc="post">3/2</ce:sup> and 3d<ce:sup loc="post">5/2</ce:sup> of Mo(VI) center (Fig. S6b) . Phase purity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Fig. S7).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The XPS spectra of compound 1 confirm that the polyoxoanion of 1 contains both V(V) and Mo(VI) centers. The binding energy peak at 517.45eV corresponds to 2p3/2 of the V(V) center (Fig. S6a) , while the peaks at 235.7 and 232.55eV are assigned to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of Mo(VI) center (Fig. S6b) . Phase purity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Fig. S7).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In summary, the reaction between a double-betaine-containing ligand and the vanadium-substituted Keggin-type POM DyH[PMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]·nH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O leads to a new POM-based 1D lanthanide-organic hybrid polymeric chain. It is found that the POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid scaffoldings can be adjusted by modifying the polyoxoanions. Moreover, it can be expected that the design and use of new double or multiple betaine-containing ligands and/or other POM precursors in such reaction systems may assemble more new POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid materials and explore their interesting multifunctional properties in luminescence, electrochemistry, magnetism and catalysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, the reaction between a double-betaine-containing ligand and the vanadium-substituted Keggin-type POM DyH[PMo11VO40]⋅nH2O leads to a new POM-based 1D lanthanide-organic hybrid polymeric chain. It is found that the POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid scaffoldings can be adjusted by modifying the polyoxoanions. Moreover, it can be expected that the design and use of new double or multiple betaine-containing ligands and/or other POM precursors in such reaction systems may assemble more new POM-based lanthanide-organic hybrid materials and explore their interesting multifunctional properties in luminescence, electrochemistry, magnetism and catalysis.

Orange crystals of DyHPMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>·nH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were formed after cooling the saturated solution and slow evaporation at room temperature. A solvent mixture (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of acetonitrile and water (v:v<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3:2) was used as a buffer layer and very carefully layered over an aqueous solution (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of L ligand (35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in a long and thin tube. Then, the fresh DyHPMo<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>VO<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>·nH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>0.04<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL mixture of acetonitrile and water (v:v<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3:1) was slowly layered over the buffer layer. [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3][PMo11VO40]⋅8H2O (1). H4PMo11VO40⋅32.5H2O  (80mg, 0.04mmol) and DyCl3⋅6H2O (16mg, 0.04mmol) were dissolved in water (4mL), and the solution was heated to saturation at 80°C in a water bath. Orange crystals of DyHPMo11VO40⋅nH2O were formed after cooling the saturated solution and slow evaporation at room temperature. A solvent mixture (10mL) of acetonitrile and water (v:v=3:2) was used as a buffer layer and very carefully layered over an aqueous solution (4mL) of L ligand (35mg, 0.1mmol) in a long and thin tube. Then, the fresh DyHPMo11VO40⋅nH2O (90mg, ~0.04mmol) in 4mL mixture of acetonitrile and water (v:v=3:1) was slowly layered over the buffer layer. The tube was sealed and left undisturbed at room temperature. After one month, the orange block crystals of 1 were obtained in the buffer layer and collected by filtration (Yield: 55% based on Mo). Anal. Calcd for C50H62N5O61PVDyMo11: C, 19.93; H, 2.06; N, 2.33; Mo, 35.09; V: 1.69. Found: C, 19.95; H, 2.04; N, 2.34; Mo, 35.15; V: 1.62. Selected IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3120(w), 3059(w), 1620(m), 1562(m), 1509(m), 1457(w), 1375(m), 1055(s), 948(s), 873(m), 796(s). The first weight loss of 6.53% in the temperature range of 50-170°C of the TG curve corresponds to eight lattice water molecules and three coordinated water molecules in 1 (calculated value 6.58)

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3][PMo11VO40]·8H2O, Mr<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3009.80, triclinic, space group P-1, a<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>16.169(3) Å, b<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>16.406(3) Å, c<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>19.632(4) Å, α<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>70.06(3)° β<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>77.98(3)° γ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>87.13(3)° V<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>4786.8(17) Å3, Z<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2, Dc<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.088<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Mg·m<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3</ce:sup>, μ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.369<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 3.02<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>θ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>25.00°, F(000)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2904, T<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>150(2) K. 36427 reflection collected, 16405 unique. The final R1 and wR2 were 0.0866 and 0.2420, respectively [I<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2σ(I)]. The crystallographic data were collected at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on the Rigaku R-axis Rapid IP diffractometer using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and IP techniques. A multi-scan absorption correction was applied. The crystal data was solved by the direct method and refined by a full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software package . All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically except the disordered solvent water molecules. H atoms on the C atoms were fixed in calculated positions. The H atoms on the lattice water molecules cannot be found from the weak residual peaks but were directly included in the final molecular formula. In the final refinement, there are still some weak residual peaks but cannot be clearly determined as solvent water molecules, thus, the SQUEEZE program  was used to estimate the left crystalline water molecules in the structure. Furthermore, on the basis of the elemental analysis, TG and the SQUEEZE calculations, another one water molecule was directly included in the final molecular formula. Selected bond lengths and angles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are listed in Table S1.</ce:simple-para>

A multi-scan absorption correction was applied. Furthermore, on the basis of the elemental analysis, TG and the SQUEEZE calculations, another one water molecule was directly included in the final molecular formula. Selected bond lengths and angles of 1 are listed in Table S1.

[Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3][PMo11VO40]⋅8H2O (1). H4PMo11VO40⋅32.5H2O  (80mg, 0.04mmol) and DyCl3⋅6H2O (16mg, 0.04mmol) were dissolved in water (4mL), and the solution was heated to saturation at 80°C in a water bath. Orange crystals of DyHPMo11VO40⋅nH2O were formed after cooling the saturated solution and slow evaporation at room temperature. A solvent mixture (10mL) of acetonitrile and water (v:v=3:2) was used as a buffer layer and very carefully layered over an aqueous solution (4mL) of L ligand (35mg, 0.1mmol) in a long and thin tube. Then, the fresh DyHPMo11VO40⋅nH2O (90mg, ~0.04mmol) in 4mL mixture of acetonitrile and water (v:v=3:1) was slowly layered over the buffer layer. The tube was sealed and left undisturbed at room temperature. After one month, the orange block crystals of 1 were obtained in the buffer layer and collected by filtration (Yield: 55% based on Mo). Anal. Calcd for C50H62N5O61PVDyMo11: C, 19.93; H, 2.06; N, 2.33; Mo, 35.09; V: 1.69. Found: C, 19.95; H, 2.04; N, 2.34; Mo, 35.15; V: 1.62. Selected IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3120(w), 3059(w), 1620(m), 1562(m), 1509(m), 1457(w), 1375(m), 1055(s), 948(s), 873(m), 796(s). The first weight loss of 6.53% in the temperature range of 50-170°C of the TG curve corresponds to eight lattice water molecules and three coordinated water molecules in 1 (calculated value 6.58)

cln_elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  shows that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1, and the basic structural unit consists of the cationic lanthanide-organic hybrid chain [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3]4+, the Keggin-type polyoxoanion [PMo11VO40]4-, and eight lattice water molecules (Fig. S1 and Fig. S2). In the cationic dysprosium-organic chain of 1, each Dy3+ ion adopts an octa-coordinated environment with five oxygen atoms derived from the carboxylate groups of three different L ligands and three coordinated water molecules ( ). The bond distances of DyO are in the range of 2.230(17)-2.592(14) Å and the ODyO bond angles vary from 52.1(5)° to 159.6(7)°. It is interesting that the L ligands can be regarded as three different types labeled with La, Lb and Lc as shown in b. Although each carboxylate group on the La and Lb ligands displays a monodentate coordination mode with one Dy center, La and Lb ligands exhibit two different configurations, that is, the La ligand adopts cis-configuration and the Lb ligand possesses trans-configuration (a and b). For Lc ligand, one carboxylate group exhibits a bidentate coordination mode with one Dy center and the other carboxylate group is protonated (a and b). Based on above coordination mode, each Dy1 atom connects Dy2 atom via two La ligands to form a cyclic-like unit (a and c). Furthermore, the Dy1 atom on each circle unit links the Dy2 atom on the other cyclic unit via the linear Lb ligand to form an infinite 1D chain. Moreover, each Dy center also connects one semi-cyclic-like Lc ligand (a and c). Such a structural feature just looks like a "train" with many semi-open cavities that can carry "guest" polyoxoanions (c).

The polyoxoanion [PMo11VO40]4- shows interesting reversible multi-electron redox processes . Thus, it is interesting to explore its electrochemical behaviors and changes when such multi-electron carrier is encapsulated into the cationic metal-organic open frameworks. Herein, the electrochemical behaviors of compound 1were investigated with the 1-modified carbon paste electrodes (1-CPE) because of its very low solubility in water and common organic solvents. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements of 1-CPE at different scan rates were measured in the potential range from +800 to -150mV in 0.5M H2SO4 +0.1 Na2SO4 (a). As shown in a, four pairs of reversible redox peaks of 1-CPE appear in the range of +800 to -150mV, and the mean peak potentials ( E  1/2 =(E cp +  E  ap)/2) are 502, 363,221 and -25mV with the scan rate of 100mV/s (Fig. S5). The reversible peak I-I' is attributable to a one-electron redox process of V center and the reversible peaks II-II', III-III' and IV-IV' correspond to a two-, four-, and six-electron redox process of Mo centers, respectively . The peak currents are proportional to the scan rate up to 200mV/s, indicating that the redox process of 1-CPE is surface-controlled (a inset).

In the electrochemical studies of POM-based hybrid materials, one of the most interesting works is to discover their potential electrocatalytic properties, since many of them can be potentially good electrocatalysts to reduce the polluting substances in water such as iodate, nitrite and hydrogen peroxide . Especially when the POMs are combined into the metal-organic frameworks, they can not only avoid the partial loss in organic and/or aqueous media but also retain the electrocatalytic activity, representing one type of ideal electrocatalysts. The electrocatalytic properties of 1-CPEs were studied toward the reduction of nitrite in an aqueous solution. At 1-CPE in a 0.5M H2SO4 +0.1 Na2SO4 aqueous solution, the CV for the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrite is shown in b. With the addition of nitrite solution, all reduction peak currents increased while the corresponding oxidation peak currents markedly decreased, revealing that nitrite was reduced by all reduced polyoxoanion species. It is worth emphasizing that the fourth reduced species shows the best electrocatalytic activity, suggesting that the increase of reduction extent of the Keggin anion species may enhance their catalytic activities. It's also noteworthy that no obvious response was observed in the range +800 to -150mV on a bare CPE and the reduction of nitrite at a bare electrode generally requires a large overpotential (b). Moreover, the peak currents of 1-CPE keep almost unchanged over 100 cycles at a scan rate of 100mV/s when the potential range is maintained between +800 and -150mV, indicating that 1-CPE possesses a relatively high stability .

Crystal data for 1: [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3][PMo11VO40]⋅8H2O, Mr=3009.80, triclinic, space group P-1, a=16.169(3) Å, b=16.406(3) Å, c=19.632(4) Å, α=70.06(3)° β=77.98(3)° γ=87.13(3)° V=4786.8(17) Å3, Z=2, Dc=2.088Mg⋅m-3, μ=2.369mm-1, 3.02<θ<25.00°, F(000)=2904, T=150(2) K. 36427 reflection collected, 16405 unique. The final R1 and wR2 were 0.0866 and 0.2420, respectively [I>2σ(I)]. The crystallographic data were collected at 150K on the Rigaku R-axis Rapid IP diffractometer using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) and IP techniques. A multi-scan absorption correction was applied. The crystal data was solved by the direct method and refined by a full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software package . All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically except the disordered solvent water molecules. H atoms on the C atoms were fixed in calculated positions. The H atoms on the lattice water molecules cannot be found from the weak residual peaks but were directly included in the final molecular formula. In the final refinement, there are still some weak residual peaks but cannot be clearly determined as solvent water molecules, thus, the SQUEEZE program  was used to estimate the left crystalline water molecules in the structure. Furthermore, on the basis of the elemental analysis, TG and the SQUEEZE calculations, another one water molecule was directly included in the final molecular formula. Selected bond lengths and angles of 1 are listed in Table S1.

metadata.title: A new organic–inorganic hybrid compound based on lanthanide-organic chain and Keggin-type polyoxometalate
